title: Drawing, "Design for "Scatter Shelf"", 2011
medium: Pen and black ink on white vellum paper
signed: Signed in black ink, lower right: FRIEDMAN BENDA
inscribed: Inscribed in black ink, lower right: NENDO ['O' contains a smiley face]. SCAttER SHELF.
provenance: Nendo; Friedman Benda Gallery until February 2013
creditline: Gift of Marc Benda and Barry Friedman, courtesy of the artist
description: Four shelf designs. From left to right, the squares of the shelves progressively get smaller. First from left: large grid shelving unit; second: two roughly overlapping grid shelving units making the squares smaller, with books, a potted plant, a frame; third:  two roughly overlapping grid shelving units making the squares even smaller, with an alarm clock, a frame, and books; fourth: two grid shelving units completely overlap each other with all previously-noted objects.
justification: This drawing is a preparatory work for the design of “scatter shelf,” a storage unit composed of 5mm glossy black acrylic shelves that have been arranged as a grid, and then stacked in three, slightly off-kilter layers.&nbsp; While the shelving unit remains structurally sound, the visual effect is kaleidoscopic, where the individual shelves appear to increase and decrease in volume depending on the viewer’s vantage point.&nbsp; nendo’s founder, Oki Sato, has referred to the experience of this effect as appearing to be “caught in a spider’s web.”&nbsp; Sato executed this drawing in preparation for the exhibition of a group of thirty-five “scatter shelves” at Friedman Benda gallery in New York.&nbsp; The drawing was reproduced on the wall at the&nbsp;entrance to the exhibition.&nbsp; With its simple ink lines, the drawing lyrically depicts the layering of the grid structures to form the complete shelving unit.&nbsp;
